posts.name: Battery Nerd - FRC #4561
posts.cooked:
Greetings, Robotics Enthusiasts!

I want to share this 3D-printed, minimal handle that was designed to encourage proper battery handling. It clamps on and off quickly, and requires less than 15 grams of filament.

[ https://makerworld.com/en/models/1015389#profileId-995541 ]( https:// FRC 4561 TerrorBytes Battery Carry Handle)

FRC 4561 Battery Carry Handle 1 994×760 70.3 KB

FRC 4561 Battery Carry Handle 1 994×760 70.3 KB

FRC 4561 Battery Carry Handle 1 994×760 70.3 KB

Prints in PLA, PETG, and Overture Easy Nylon all performed well. I recommend PETG for its durability and a high-visibility color (like Prusa Orange) as a visual reminder to handle batteries with care.

The battery shown is having the cables upgraded for the Reefscape season. Two years ago, the TerrorBytes started naming their batteries to honor underrecognized individuals who have made significant contributions to science and humanity.

2025-01-17 22.36.09 adj 1920×1538 187 KB

2025-01-17 22.36.09 adj 1920×1538 187 KB

2025-01-17 22.36.09 adj 1920×1538 187 KB

More often than not, when the robot does something unexpected in a match, the battery isn’t the culprit. Instead, the true issue remains hidden, waiting to cause more trouble.

Check your power log for clues, rapid voltage drops without corresponding increases in current often point to a poor connection. Loose battery terminals are the most common connection issue, often caused by lifting the battery by its cables. If the cables can be wiggled with just three fingers, they are too loose for match play.

Give the battery handle a try and let me know what you think.  Treat your batteries with care, and they will return the favor on the field!

Shane Battery Nerd Mentor, FRC 4561 TerrorBytes

link_counts.title: 4561 The TerrorBytes | 2025 Build Thread | Open Alliance

posts.name: D_Price (1708 Co-Lead Mentor)
posts.cooked: Just asking, but have the handles been tested with cables attached to the terminals of the batteries?

posts.name: Battery Nerd - FRC #4561
posts.cooked:
Yes, the battery handles have been tested with batteries with 6ga, 4ga, and 2ga cables. With no trouble.

I have a bunch of our old team batteries for testing battery recovery methods, and for evaluating battery testers. Since most do not have cables attached, it was easy to stack them and tape some together to see how much the handle can lift.

1 - battery - no problem 2 - batteries - no problem 3 - batteries - not sure this is a good idea, but it holds 4 - batteries -  both hooks snap off when lifting the stack

I will repeat the exercise tomorrow with an Overture Easy Nylon version and see if it holds up as well at the Prusa PETG.

A few handles broke testing motion limits (trying to rotate the handle 90 degrees sideways or forwards). Not surprising.

A few PLA versions also broke on batteries on the floor when something passing by caught the edge of the hook.

Thanks, Shane

posts.name: D_Price (1708 Co-Lead Mentor)
posts.cooked: Thanks Shane for the follow up! These look awesome!  I might try printing a couple with NylonX filament to test rigidity from my end.

posts.name: Battery Nerd - FRC #4561
posts.cooked:
The 3D printed battery handle in this photo used just under 14 grams of PETG, and has been supporting three batteries (around 17.5 kg) for over 24 hours.

So the strength to weight ratio is greater than 1200.

This is the first time testing overnight, so I set a chair and empty cardboard box under the batteries to catch them if the handle cold-flowed and failed, or if something in my test setup failed.

IMG_3531 1920×3008 545 KB

IMG_3531 1920×3008 545 KB

IMG_3531 1920×3008 545 KB

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: Did you end up trying these out? If so how were they?

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: How well does this handle tolerate dynamic loads and shock loads like when someone picks up the battery very quickly or swings it around to place it somewhere?

philso:

someone picks up the battery very quickly or swings it around to place it somewhere?

Quickly would be interesting, but you shouldn’t be swinging the battery around in the first place.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked:
I printed this with PLA+ and swung a battery around rapidly and it did break (this was a couple months ago): image 1370×728 105 KB Picking it up quickly seemed fine though. But as @FinIce mentioned, if someone is swinging around a battery, you should really be telling them not to do that.

image 1370×728 105 KB

image 1370×728 105 KB

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
There is what people should or should not do, then there are the things that they will do despite any instructions, warnings and/or common sense.

A well thought out solution should “fail gracefully”, or not fail at all, even when people do things that they should not do, especially when the consequences are severe.
